content.description: 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Beluga Boulders Area. Located on largest Boulder . Route faces East. This climb is easy to find as it is the first boulder you come to. The face to the right has been top roped (5.11-) This is the best of the climbs in the Beluga Boulders.
content.location: As you get to the top of the hill, this is the first climb you come to, on the largest boulder you see. The route faces east, and is sort of in a corridor/jumble of boulders.

climbs.name: Oral Sturgeon
climbs.fa: Tucker Tech, Todd Gordon, Kelby Burnham

content.description: Up at the Beluga Boulders (Top of the mountain above The Bond Boulders), over on the left is a very obvious spliter crack (faces east). start with and O W crack, then splitter hands, then gritty hands over a roof ( crux). No fixed anchor on top, no fixed gear on the climb.
content.protection: Pretty much a full rack of trad gear; doubles on most pieces, especially 1" to 3". There are alot of gear placements on this pitch.
content.location: Top of the mountain, and over on the left side of the Beluga Boulders.

climbs.name: Eat Beluga
climbs.fa: Tim Pinar, Brett Pinar, Tucker Tech, Todd Gordon

content.description: 3 or 4 bolts (some gear) to a 2 bolt anchor. Route faces north and is in the northern most boulders at the top of the hill, above the Bond Boulders at Split Rock Area.
content.protection: Some gear needed; mostly small to med.
content.location: Go to the N. most of all the boulders in the Beluga Boulders area. This boulder is there, off to the left a little bit, and the route faces north.

content.description: 4 bolt face to 2 bolt anchor. This route is located on a very large boulder up a ridge of boulders about 1/4 mile before the Bond Boulders. The "butthole" is a small black pocket part way up the route. South facing. Basically, you walk right past this climb, as you are hiking up to the Beluga Boulders.
content.location: Hiking up the hillside to get to the Beluga Boulders, above the Bond Boulders, you hike right past this climb.
